quoteFirst: ' At the first shot Arabi and his second in command took horse and galloped to Belbeis, where they caught a train for Cairo. Most of the other officers, as the reports of killed and wounded show, did the same. The Egyptians fired their first shot at
quoteLast: , and at 6.45 the English had possession of Arabi's headquarters and the canal bridge.
title: History for ready reference, Volumes 1 to 5
author: Larned, J. N. (Josephus Nelson), 1836-1913

quoteFirst: Light a pipe and sit down in a comfortable place, if such there be, and leave the sinner alone until the spirit does move her to stir. At some time or other, varying from
quoteLast: hours, she will want the lure badly enough. Then let her come for it. Keep her waiting on or stooping at the lure till she has had a good dose of it, and if she goes off to perch again, wait again till she will work for her living.
title: The Art and Practice of Hawking
author: Michell, E. B. (Edward Blair), 1843-; Lodge, George Edward, 1860-1954 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Everything worked out exactly as the Dumpling had planned it. At
quoteLast: the vanguards of the advancing armies were seen approaching from Royal Mint Street and the Minories. Almost at the very moment that the soldiers were preparing to fire, the windows of the tea warehouse were opened, and a deadly volley poured upon the unfortunate gunners by the riflemen who had been concealed within its walls.
title: The Dumpling
author: Kernahan, Coulson, 1858-1943; Wood, Stanley L., 1866-1928 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: At 7 p.m. we moved forward again and at 11.30 p.m. reached and occupied shell holes just west of Monchy, very fortunately shown on the map as Orange Hill. On our arrival here orders were received from the 9th Brigade to co-operate with other units of the Brigade and attack at
quoteLast: A conference of Company Commanders was hastily called when the plan of attack was discussed and instructions quickly detailed, and at 12.10 midnight, companies had moved off by platoons to take up assembly positions in the jumping-off trench held by the Royal Canadian Regiment.
title: The 116th Battalion in France
author: Allen, E. P. S. (Evelyn Prestwood Seymour), 1885-1972

quoteLast: on August 27, 1918, by the Second and Third Canadian Divisions, in the face of increased opposition, under a uniformly good initial barrage.
title:
The Story of the Great War, Volume 8
Victory with the Allies; Armistice; Peace Congress; Canada's War Organizations and vast War Industries; Canadian Battles Overseas
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]; Miller, Francis Trevelyan, 1877-1959 [Editor]

quoteFirst: By the depot clock it was
quoteLast: . A train was being called, and the sing-song chant informed him that it was bound for "Sa-anta Bar-bra--Sa-an Louis Oh bispo--Sa-linas--Sa-an 'Osay--Sa-an Fransisco, and a-a-ll points north!"
title: The Lookout Man

quoteFirst: On the 21st of March the superior passage takes place at 5 minutes to 11 at night; on the following night four minutes earlier, or at 9 minutes to 11. In three months the culmination takes place 6 hours earlier, or at
quoteLast: . In six months, _i.e._ on Sept. 22, it culminates at 10.55 in the morning, being vertically below the pole at the same hour in the evening.
title: Astronomical Myths: Based on Flammarions's "History of the Heavens"
author: Blake, J. F. (John Frederick), 1839-1906; Flammarion, Camille, 1842-1925

quoteFirst: To the Highland Brigade,[64] under General Alison, fell the task of carrying the lines to the left. The first shots were fired at them at
quoteLast: from an Egyptian picket posted about 150 yards in front of the intrenchments, then visible 300 yards distant from the Highlanders. Immediately afterwards the enemy opened with artillery and then with musketry.
title: The Egyptian campaigns, 1882 to 1885
author: Royle, Charles, 1882-1936

quoteLast: Schmitz graciously told me I might go up to my supper, though the law in the statute books stood five. Everybody upstairs in the main kitchen, as I made my way to the service elevator, spoke kindly and asked in the accents of at least ten different nationalities how I liked my job.
title: Working With the Working Woman
author: Parker, Cornelia Stratton, 1885-1972

quoteFirst: She had been accorded the privilege of setting the clock on this stump, and I saw it shining in her hand as she paused for a moment to glance back at the circle of gentlemen who were awaiting her movements. The hands of the clock stood at
quoteLast: , though I scarcely noted the fact at the time, for her eyes were on mine, and as she passed me she spoke:
title: The Doctor, his Wife, and the Clock
author: Green, Anna Katharine, 1846-1935

quoteFirst: Bos Tyler and Jack Hicks attended upon Mace. Travers at the opening was an immense favourite, 2 to 1 being offered on him. It was
quoteLast: o’clock when the men’s toilettes were completed and they stood up for

quoteFirst: Her departure was always unexpected, her moods changed with so much rapidity. “Look!” she said, pointing where the clock on St. Peter’s church showed above the bushes. “
quoteLast: . In five minutes my mother’s tea-hour. It is like growing old. I go to gossip. Good-bye.”
title: John Sherman; and, Dhoya
author: Yeats, W. B. (William Butler), 1865-1939

quoteLast: by the clock on the wall before him. It therefore wanted but five minutes of six, the hour of the wedding, at home, the difference in time being just an hour. In the years of his exile, by way of enhancing the vividness of his dreams of home, he had calculated exactly the difference in time from various points in Colorado, so that he could say to himself, “Now Mary is putting the babies to bed;” “Now it is her own bedtime;” “Now she is waking up;” or “Now the church-bells are ringing, and she is walking to church.
title:
At Pinney's Ranch
1898
author: Bellamy, Edward, 1850-1898

quoteLast: he started to fidget with his rifle, and then suddenly springing up on the fire step with a muttered, "I'll send over a couple of souvenirs to Fritz, so that he'll miss me when I leave," he stuck his rifle over the top and fired two shots, when "crack" went a bullet and he tumbled off the step, fell into the mud at the bottom of the trench, and lay still in a huddled heap with a bullet hole in his forehead.
title:
"Over the Top," by an American Soldier Who Went
Together with Tommy's Dictionary of the Trenches
author: Empey, Arthur Guy, 1883-1963
